awd_titl_txt: Accounting for Conformational Dynamics in Post-Translational Phosphorylation of Signaling Proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Accounting for Conformational Dynamics in Post-Translational Phosphorylation of Signaling Proteins

To thrive, cells must regulate dense networks of protein-protein interactions that drive basic processes such as cell growth, division, and death.  One well-known regulatory mechanism is "post-translational phosphorylation" - the reversible addition of phosphate groups to specific amino acids within a protein. Phosphorylation can alter protein binding specificity, enzymatic activity, or sub-cellular location, thereby regulating its interaction with other proteins. But just how this comes about is not yet clear. In fact, an atomic level explanation for how site-specific phosphorylation changes a protein's interaction properties remains an open challenge. This project addresses this challenge by investigating the effects of post-translational phosphorylation on protein conformational dynamics. The protein segments subject to phosphorylation are often the same segments involved in intermolecular interactions. Critically, they often have conformational flexibility that defies explanation by standard biochemical analysis. By investigating how these dynamic protein segments convert phosphorylation into functional change, this project will provide insight into a widespread, yet poorly understood aspect of protein phosphorylation. Gaining this insight is a necessary step toward understanding and manipulating protein interaction networks. This project will bring interdisciplinary educational opportunities to students at early stages of college by developing freshmen courses that introduce physical principles based on biophysical phenomena. This project will also train doctoral students and undergraduate research interns, including members of underrepresented groups, to become highly qualified scientists in the area biophysics and computational biology; the cultivation of such expertise is vital to keep the U.S. competitiveness in research and in the global economy.

The project will combine liquid-state multi-dimensional Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, and mutagenesis to map how site-specific phosphorylation impacts protein dynamics and protein-substrate interactions in the mitotic signaling protein, Pin1. Pin1 interactions with other proteins are sensitive to both conformational dynamics and post-translational phosphorylation. This proposal will determine the extent to which phosphorylation exploits electrostatic networks to achieve long-range site-to-site communication (allostery). This project will also define how phosphorylation of intrinsically disordered regions nevertheless elicit functional changes at remote binding sites.  Because Pin1 interacts with numerous other signaling proteins, results of this project will give broad insight into the mechanisms by which dynamic protein segments convert phosphorylation into functional change. This project will also include development of general protein NMR methods to better characterize dynamic electrostatic interactions in proteins, and their description in terms of conformational ensembles. This project is supported by Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Phosphorylation of amino acid residues is one of the major types of post-translational proteins sustaining proper cell growth and development. Post-translational phosphorylation involves enzyme-catalyzed attachment of phosphate groups to the side chain hydroxyls of residues including Tyr, Thr, and Ser. The phosphorylation serves to change protein properties such as enzyme activity (up or down), susceptibility to degradation, or subcellular location.

While the effects of phosphorylation may be well-understood, the underlying mechanisms are not. In particular, atomic degrees of freedom enabling long-range conformational perturbations from post-translational phosphorylation remain unclear.  

Our project work investigated this question through studies of human Pin1, a two-domain peptidyl-prolyl isomerase targeting pS/T-P motifs in other cell-cycle proteins. Other research groups had identified serines (S16, S65, S71, and S138) with post-translational phosphorylation affecting Pin1 isomerase activity and subcellular location.

We investigated the atomic-level bases for these phosphorylation effects by generating phosphomimetic S->E mutants of Pin1, (e.g. S71E a mimicking pS16 etc.) We characterized the resulting perturbations to Pin1 conformation and activity using multi-dimensional Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (NMR) and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations.

Our combined results extend our understanding of how a local event, such as serine phosphorylation, can instigate long-range perturbations.  Specifically: they suggest that such long-range effects reflect the phosphorylation of residues that participate in collective fluctuations of the unmodified protein. That is, the residue-to-be-phosphorylated is already part of a network of inter-residue interactions establishing long-range correlations in the unmodified protein. Those correlations are perturbed upon phosphorylation, producing experimentally observed long-range effects (perturbations at sites distal from the phosphorylated residue).

The main results driving our statement above are summarized in the subsections below. 

i) Post-translational phosphorylation of surface residues belonging to extended networks of electrostatic couplings.  S71 lies in a solvent-exposed catalytic loop in the PPIase domain; isomerization occurs in a hydrophobic pocket ~ 14-15 ? distant. Yet, isomerase activity reduces upon phosphorylation of S71(S71E), pointing to a long-range effect.  Our findings suggest that the effect stems from S71 being part of an extended network of polar/electrostatic interactions that relay surface effects to the domain interior [Mahoney et al. J. Mol Biol (2018) 430, 710-721]. These include ?latch? interactions involving long side-chain residues (Arg, Lys) that couple S71 to residues in the (a2/a3) portion of the active site that directly contact the substrate proline. The relay mechanism of pS71 likely illustrates a common strategy for long-range information transfer.

ii) Post-translational phosphorylation exploiting pre-existing correlations between interdomain distance fluctuations, and intradomain conformation. Both pS16(S16E) and pS138(S138E) perturb the transient interdomain contact we observed for apo WT-Pin1. pS138 was understandable, given its location within one of the two interfaces of domain contact (WW domain Loop II, residues 27-29; PPIase domain a4/b6/b7 region, residues 136-144. By contrast, pS16(S16E) is on the opposite side of the WW domain; it lacks direct contact with the PPIase domain. Yet, it reduces the level of interdomain contact, in manner similar to that caused by the binding of phosphopeptide substrates (e.g. pCdc25C) at S16.

A plausible mechanism emerged from paramagnetic relaxation experiments, MD simulations [Zhang et al. J Biol Chem (2020) 295(49) 16585-16603), and mutation studies of the determinants of WW domain core stability [Zhang et al., Structure, (2018) 26 1474-1485).   Specifically, the equilibrium conformational fluctuations of unmodified (or apo) WT-Pin1 exhibit correlations between interdomain and intradomain degrees of freedom; fluctuations that increase domain separation simultaneously promote intradomain compaction. These correlated fluctuations give rise to multi-domain conformations resembling that of phosphorylated S16; namely, a more compact WW domain and weaker domain contact reflecting a larger average domain separation. Those conformations stabilize upon actual introduction of the phosphate group to S16, and manifests as the decreased interdomain contact observed in experiment.

The above mechanism is "conformational selection", but extended to interdomain degrees of freedom characteristic of multi-domain proteins. It relies on features common to modular signaling proteins, and may therefore have broad relevance.

Publications:

 “Coupled intra- and interdomain dynamics support domain cross-talk in Pin1”, Zhang M, Frederick TE, VanPelt J, Case DA, Peng JW, J Biol Chem (2020) Dec 4;295(49): 16585-16603.

 “Propagated Perturbations from a Peripheral Mutation Show Interactions Supporting WW Domain Thermostability”, Zhang M, Case DA, Peng JW, Structure (2018), Nov 6;26(11):1474-1485.

“Extended Impact of Pin1 Catalytic Loop Phosphorylation Revealed by S71E Phosphomimetic”, Mahoney BJ, Zhang M, Zintsmaster JS, Peng JW, J Mol Biol (2018) Mar 2;430(5):710-721
